© 2023 Bruce Monger
Section I
Historical Perspective Leading to our Current Understanding of El Niño 
Southern Oscillation (ENSO)

© 2023 Bruce Monger
The original definition of El Niño goes back to 
18th or 19th century when Peruvian sailors 
coined  the term to describe a warm 
southward current that appeared annually 
near Christmas time off the  Peruvian coast. 
Hence the name El Niño = Spanish for “The 
Child” == “Christ Child".  


The warm, southward current occasionally 
(every 3 to 7 years) seemed much more 
intense than usual and eventually the term 
 
El Niño came to refer primarily to these 
occasional extreme events
Annual Cycle of Sea Surface 
Temperature
History of the Term 
 
El Niño

© 2023 Bruce Monger
El Niño
The Roughly Periodic (3-7 years) Occurrence of 
Prolonged (ca. 8 months) Warming of Coastal Waters off 
of Peru and Ecuador

© 2023 Bruce Monger
The Southern Oscillation

© 2023 Bruce Monger
In the 1920’s Sir Gilbert 
Walker Analyzed Atmospheric 
Pressure Data Measured at 
Darwin Australia and Tahiti 
and Noticed Some 
Remarkable Correlations in 
the Two Data Sets
In Search of Atmospheric 
Teleconnections
© 2023 Bruce Monger

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Why Are The Two Weather Stations So 
Well-Correlated?

© 2023 Bruce Monger
The explanation is 
found by taking a closer 
look at the idealized 
Hadley Circulation 


In particular the 
East-
West
 component of the 
tropical 
Hadley Cell
The Answer...

© 2023 Bruce Monger
3-D View of Idealized Hadley 
Circulation
Winds at the Ocean Surface
 
✦
Rush toward the equator 
✦
Coriolis force turns the winds to 
the right to blow from 
east to 
west (Classic Trade Winds).


Winds Aloft
 
✦
Rush away from the equator 
✦
Coriolis force turns the winds to 
the right to blow from 
west to 
east (Opposite of Trade Winds).

© 2023 Bruce Monger
1.
Differences due to unequal 
heating of land and ocean


2.
Land heats more strongly than 
adjacent ocean in summer and 
cools more than adjacent 
ocean in winter - due to 
differences in specific heat of 
rock and seawater.
East-West Pattern of 
The Hadley Circulation

© 2023 Bruce Monger
1.
Winds 
at the ocean surface
 move toward 
the equator, but are deflected by Coriolis 
toward the west
 to form surface trade 
winds.


2.
Winds 
aloft 
move away from the equator, but 
are deflected by Coriolis 
toward the east
 to 
complete 
the
 
Walker-Circulation Cell
 
3.
Sir Gilbert Walker discovered this east/west 
atmospheric circulation cell 
and
 
that it 
periodically reversed direction! 
Walker-Circulation
 
East-West Atmospheric Circulation Cell

© 2023 Bruce Monger
The Southern Oscillation 
is 
the
 
periodic reversal
 
of the Walker Circulation 
Cell


Note the reversal of the 
high/low SLP pattern 
between the two 
conditions
Normal Conditions
The Southern 
Oscillation 
Low
 
SLP
High
 
SLP
SLP = Atmosphere Pressure at Sea Level 
High
 
SLP
Low
 
SLP
Reversed Conditions
© 2023 Bruce Monger

© 2023 Bruce Monger
The Coherent Change (
Periodic Reversal — Every 3 to 7 years
) in 
the East-West Circulation Cell Over the Pacific (Walker Cell) Resulting 
in Coherent Changes in Atmospheric Pressure Patterns, Precipitation 
Patterns and Wind Direction
The Southern Oscillation

© 2023 Bruce Monger
El Nino Southern Oscillation (ENSO)
 
Coupled Ocean-Atmospheric Interactions
1.
Roughly periodic (3-7 years) occurrence of prolonged (ca. 8 months) warming of coastal 
waters off of Peru and Ecuador


2.
Coherent change in the east-west atmospheric circulation cell over the Pacific (Walker Cell) 
resulting in coherent changes in atmospheric pressure patterns, precipitation patterns and 
wind direction


3.
And Much Much More...
In 1969 Jacob Bjerknes proposed that there was a physical connection between the 
oceanographic
 and 
atmospheric variations
 and now the oceanic (El Niño) and the 
atmospheric (Southern Oscillation) aspects 
are often combined
 in the single term: 
 
'
El Niño Southern Oscillation
' (ENSO)
 that encompasses both the ocean and the 
atmosphere

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Section II
ENSO Details

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Under Normal 
Conditions
1. The Trade Winds transport and 
pile up warm surface water
 on 
the western side of the Pacific 
to create a thick (200 meters) 
pool of very warm ocean water
 
called: 
“the warm pool”. 
2. The piled up water tilts the 
thermocline deeper in the west 
and shallower 
in the east.

© 2023 Bruce Monger
The El Nino Southern Oscillation Patterns 
https://www.mdpi.com/2073-4433/9/3/94/htm

© 2023 Bruce Monger
La Nina 
Exceptionally Strong Trade Winds, 
Equatorial Upwelling and Cooling in the 
Eastern Pacific
El Niño 
Exceptionally Weak or Reversed Trade 
Winds, Little or No Equatorial Upwelling 
and Strong Warming in the Eastern Pacific
Normal 
Normal Trade Winds, Upwelling and 
Cooling in the Eastern Pacific
Sea Surface Temperature Patterns During La Nina, 
Normal and El Nino Conditions in the Pacific

© 2023 Bruce Monger
See:  https://theconversation.com/el-nino-has-rapidly-become-stronger-and-stranger-according-to-coral-records-115560
Two Kinds of El Niño 
Eastern
 
Pacific 
(Traditional)


Central
 
Pacific
 El Niño

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Central Pacific 
 
El Niño
Eastern Pacific 
(Traditional) 
El Niño

© 2023 Bruce Monger
1.
A simple index (i.e., a single number) used to describe the 
severity of El Niño conditions - i.e., the strength of the reversal 
in the Walker Circulation


2.
Traditionally defined as the normalized difference in 
atmospheric pressure measured at Darwin Australia and Tahiti, 
but more elaborate and robust metrics also exist.
ENSO Index:
© 2023 Bruce Monger

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Red = El Niño Conditions


Blue = La Niña Conditions
ENSO Index
http://www.esrl.noaa.gov/psd/enso/mei/

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Warming of the surface water off of Peru during an El Niño Event is part of a 
much greater warming event covering large parts of the eastern tropical Pacific 
and
 reaching down to the thermocline
El Nino Conditions
Normal Conditions

El Niño’s Progression: 1997-1998 El Nino
✦
March
: Westerly Wind Burst north of 
Australia


✦
April
: Kelvin Wave Reaches South 
America


✦
May
: Water Piles up off of South 
America


✦
June
: High Sea-Level Spreads North 
and South

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Question
What should happen to 
global-average 
temperature
 when the thick warm pool of water in 
the western Pacific spreads out over a large area 
of the equatorial Pacific during an El Nino period? 
a)  Global Temperature Should:  Go Up


b)  Global Temperature Should:  Go Down


c)  Global Temperature Should:  Stay About 
the Same
The 
Correct Answer
 is 
(a)
 temperatures will 
go up
 as the area of warm water in 
contact with the atmosphere increases and allows the ocean to give up some of  its 
stored heat to the atmosphere

© 2023 Bruce Monger

Section IV
Teleconnections
: 
 
Environmental Change Linked 
Indirectly
 to El Niño

© 2023 Bruce Monger
El Niño-Related Changes 
in Global Climate
Global-Scale 
Connections

© 2023 Bruce Monger
The answer to how El Niño can 
influence weather patterns around to 
globe lies in what El Niño can do the 
the Jet Streams that circle the globe
Impact on Subtropical 
and Polar Jet Streams

© 2023 Bruce Monger
1.
Cold and warm air masses 
are separated by the Jet 
Stream


2.
Prevailing wind direction at 
a given location is also 
strongly Influenced by the 
Position of the Jet Stream
Jet Stream Impacts 
on Weather

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Jet streams have wave-like properties 
and just as a disturbance in water 
causes a wave to propagate outward 
from a disturbance, so too can a 
regional disturbance in the jet stream 
position
 propagate around the globe 
in wave-like fashion
.  


ENSO produces such a disturbance in 
the Pacific Jet Stream that can then 
propagate around the world.
The Jet Stream’s North/South Position Is
 
Wave-Like

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Changes in the Jet Stream During El Niño and La Nina

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Effects of El Niño on Pacific and Atlantic Hurricanes
https://www.climate.gov/news-features/blogs/enso/impacts-el-niño-and-la-niña-hurricane-season
Eastern Pacific:
 El Nino gives 
rise to warm ocean waters 
and 
increases
 hurricanes
.


Atlantic
: El Nino increases 
vertical sheer in the atmosphere 
that breaks apart hurricane 
chimney formation and
 
reduced
 hurricanes
.

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Current Status of El Niño
https://www.climate.gov/news-features/blogs/september-2023-enso-outlook-el-nino-convo
El Niño is 
expected to stick around at 
least through January-March 2024. 


There is now around a 71% chance 
that this event peaks as a strong El 
Niño this winter.

© 2023 Bruce Monger
The 2015-2016 El Nino Warming Effect, When Super-Imposed on the Multi-
Decadal Global Warming Trend, Was Disastrous for Coral Reefs!!
1997-1998
2015-2016
1981-1982
El Ninos are nothing new. They temporarily raise global 
average temperatures. However, when these temporary 
warming events are super imposed on the human-
caused multi-decadal warming they have increasingly 
devastating effects on coral reef mortality

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Other Natural Climate Variations That Can 
Temporarily Warm and Cool the Earth...
1.
El Niño Southern Oscillation (ENSO)


2.
North Atlantic Oscillation (NAO)


3.
Atlantic Multi-Decadal Oscillation (AMO)


4.
Pacific Decadal Oscillation (PDO)


5.
Arctic Oscillation (AO)
But in All Cases they are Superimposed on a Very Large 
Multi-Decadal Trend that IS human-caused global warming

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Positive NAO 
✦
Strong pressure difference 
between Iceland and Azores


✦
Stronger Westerly Winds 
Located More Northward
Negative NAO 
✦
Weak pressure difference 
between Iceland and Azores


✦
Weaker Westerly Winds
 
Located More Southward
North Atlantic Oscillation (NAO)

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Pacific Decadal Oscillation (PDO)
Positive Phase: 
North Pacific cooler than normal


Equatorial Pacific warmer than normal
Negative Phase: 
North Pacific warmer than normal


Equatorial Pacific cooler than normal

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Atlantic Multi-Decadal Oscillation Derived from 
Global SST Data 
Time Variation of AMO
similar colors rise and fall in unison from 
year to year or decade to decade.


purple and red colors are out of phase - 
years or decades of high temperatures for 
red means low temperatures for purple 
regions for the same year or decade
Spatial Coherence of AMO

© 2023 Bruce Monger
In 
All 
Cases
 — The 
temporary warming 
and cooling effects of 
natural climate 
oscillations 
are 
superimposed
 on a 
very large multi-
decadal warming 
trend that represents 
human-caused global 
warming signal
Human-Caused Global Warming is a 
Multi-Decadal 
Trend 
Temperatures are Relative to Base Period 1951-1980
http://data.giss.nasa.gov/gistemp/graphs/

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Summary
1.
Besides El Niño Southern Oscillation (ENSO) there are a large 
number of other natural climate oscillations that change phase 
(sea surface temperature pattern and wind velocity pattern) on 
the order of decades


2.
When examining the issue of global warming, one needs to take 
into account natural climate variability that can occur on the order 
of decades!


3.
Global Warming is a Multi-Decadal Trend with natural decadal 
oscillations superimposed on that trend!
